elements.content: A systematic variation of diamine ligands, TED, Bipy, and Bpe [TED = triethylenediamine, Bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, and Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene], pillaring 2-fold (6,3) layers constructed from metallic trinuclear SBUs and flexible CTC ligands gives rise to a series of porous metal−organic frameworks, Cd3(CTC)2(TED)(H2O)2·(H3O)2Cl2 (1), Cd3(CTC)2(Bipy)(DMF)2·(DMF)(H2O)2 (2), Cd3(CTC)2(Bpe)(DMF)2·(DMF)(H2O)2 (3), Zn3(CTC)2(Bipy)·(DMF)(H2O)2 (4), and Zn3(CTC)2(Bpe)·(DMF)(H2O)2 (5) (compounds 1–5 named JUC-34, JUC-44, JUC-45, JUC-46, JUC-47, respectively, JUC-Jilin University, China, CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate and DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide). These open frameworks have been synthesized under mild conditions possessing three-dimensional connectivity with interconnecting pores and the same (43)2(46·618·84) topology. The water adsorption isotherms of these compounds show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions.

The water adsorption isotherms of these compounds show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions.

elements.content: Microporous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention because of their intriguing topologies and exploitable properties for potential applications such as adsorption, separation, luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, ion exchange, and catalysis. Compared with conventional porous materials, such as zeolites or activated carbons, these coordination polymers have greater potential because of their tunable framework based on metal ions with various coordination geometries and multifunctional bridging organic ligands. Much effort has been devoted to the development, design, and synthesis of novel porous metal−organic frameworks. Recently, the groups of Kitagawa, Seki, Kim, Chen, and Hupp have been particularly interested in pillared frameworks for their functional properties and dynamic features. The so-called “pillaring” strategy in designing metal−organic open frameworks involves using appropriate bidentate spacer ligands acting as pillars to connect with well-defined two-dimensional (2D) layers either in a one-pot reaction or in two separate steps. The advantage of this synthetic method is that it promises to produce a wide variety of porous MOF materials with structures that can be predicted and tunable pore sizes. It has been demonstrated that such a method to obtain pillar-layered structures, analogous to natural clays and zeolites, is rational and effective for the construction of three-dimensional porous frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Microporous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention because of their intriguing topologies and exploitable properties for potential applications such as adsorption, separation, luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, ion exchange, and catalysis. Compared with conventional porous materials, such as zeolites or activated carbons, these coordination polymers have greater potential because of their tunable framework based on metal ions with various coordination geometries and multifunctional bridging organic ligands. Much effort has been devoted to the development, design, and synthesis of novel porous metal-organic frameworks. Recently, the groups of Kitagawa, Seki, Kim, Chen, and Hupp have been particularly interested in pillared frameworks for their functional properties and dynamic features. The so-called "pillaring" strategy in designing metal-organic open frameworks involves using appropriate bidentate spacer ligands acting as pillars to connect with well-defined two-dimensional (2D) layers either in a one-pot reaction or in two separate steps. The advantage of this synthetic method is that it promises to produce a wide variety of porous MOF materials with structures that can be predicted and tunable pore sizes. It has been demonstrated that such a method to obtain pillar-layered structures, analogous to natural clays and zeolites, is rational and effective for the construction of three-dimensional porous frameworks.

elements.content: In previous work, we have briefly reported on the synthesis and characterization of a three-dimensional network structure Cd3(CTC)2(TED)(H2O)2·(H3O)2Cl2 (1) (CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate and TED = triethylenediamine) which has 2-fold alternate (6,3) Cd3(CTC)2 layers connected by TED acting as a linear pillar ligand. This possesses channels with a 7.2 × 8.4 Å2 cross-section and exhibits substantial water adsorption behavior. CTC seems an encouraging organic linker, exhibiting a variety of flexible coordination forms as a saturated cyclic carboxylate. In this paper, we expand on this study to describe the syntheses and characterization of a family of coordination polymers Cd3(CTC)2(Bipy)(DMF)2·(DMF)(H2O)2 (2), Cd3(CTC)2(Bpe)(DMF)2·(DMF)(H2O)2 (3), Zn3(CTC)2(Bipy)·(DMF)(H2O)2 (4), and Zn3(CTC)2(Bpe)·(DMF)(H2O)2 (5) [Bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine; Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, and DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide], having a 3D noninterpenetrating network structure with similar 2-fold alternate (6,3) [M3(CTC)2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) layers pillared by the Bipy or Bpe ligand. The water sorption and luminescent properties have been investigated. Meanwhile, compounds 1–5 could be described as a binodal (3,8)-connected net with 8-connected (trinuclear SBU of M3(CO2)6N2) and 3-connected (CTC ligand) nodes, and its Schläfli symbol is (43)2(46·618·84).

This possesses channels with a 7.2 × 8.4 Å2 cross-section and exhibits substantial water adsorption behavior. CTC seems an encouraging organic linker, exhibiting a variety of flexible coordination forms as a saturated cyclic carboxylate. In this paper, we expand on this study to describe the syntheses and characterization of a family of coordination polymers Cd3(CTC)2(Bipy)(DMF)2⋅(DMF)(H2O)2 (2), Cd3(CTC)2(Bpe)(DMF)2⋅(DMF)(H2O)2 (3), Zn3(CTC)2(Bipy)⋅(DMF)(H2O)2 (4), and Zn3(CTC)2(Bpe)⋅(DMF)(H2O)2 (5) [Bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine; Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, and DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide], having a 3D noninterpenetrating network structure with similar 2-fold alternate (6,3) [M3(CTC)2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) layers pillared by the Bipy or Bpe ligand. The water sorption and luminescent properties have been investigated. Meanwhile, compounds 1-5 could be described as a binodal (3,8)-connected net with 8-connected (trinuclear SBU of M3(CO2)6N2) and 3-connected (CTC ligand) nodes, and its Schläfli symbol is (43)2(46⋅618⋅84).

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400–4000 cm−1 region) on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400-4000 cm-1 region) on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).

elements.content: A mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (20 mg, 0.1 mmol), CTC (60 mg, 0.3 mmol), and TED (10 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (5 mL), H2O (2 mL), and C2H5OH (5 mL) at room temperature in a 50 mL beaker. The mixture was left undisturbed at 65 °C for 3 days to give colorless crystals. Yield: 61% (based on cadmium). The complex was stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents such as acetone, methanol, ethanol, dichloromethane, acetonitrile, chloroform, DMF, and DMSO. Elemental anal. Calcd C24H40N2O16Cl2Cd3 (1023.88): C, 28.13; H, 3.94; N, 2.74. Found: C, 28.33; H, 3.92; N, 2.70. FTIR (KBr): ν = 3408 (m), 1558 (s), 1419 (s), 1361 (s), 1217 (m), 1132 (w), 983 (w), 922 (w), 787 (m), 710 (m), 658 (m), 577 (m) cm−1.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for 1–5 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all nonhydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of complexes 1–5 are listed in Table and Tables S1−S5 in the , respectively. Crystal drawings were produced by cerius2 soft. CCDC-281927 (1), CCDC-631593 (2), CCDC-631594 (3), CCDC-631595 (4), and CCDC-631596 (5) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. X-ray Crystallographic Study

Diffraction intensities for 1-5 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all nonhydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of complexes 1-5 are listed in Table  and Tables S1-S5 in the , respectively. Crystal drawings were produced by cerius2 soft. CCDC-281927 (1), CCDC-631593 (2), CCDC-631594 (3), CCDC-631595 (4), and CCDC-631596 (5) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K.; fax (44) 1223-336-003; e-mail deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Water Sorption Isotherm

Water sorption isotherm studies were performed by measuring the increase in weight at equilibrium as a function of relative pressure. The weight of sample was measured by a Cahn 2000 electrobalance and the adsorbate (H2O) was added incrementally and manually.

elements.content: The structures of 1–5 are all 3D periodic frameworks where the carboxylate groups of CTC ligands coordinate to the metal centers in at least two of the following modes: bridging unidentate, chelating bidentate, chelating/bridging bidentate, and bidentate (Chart ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The structures of 1-5 are all 3D periodic frameworks where the carboxylate groups of CTC ligands coordinate to the metal centers in at least two of the following modes: bridging unidentate, chelating bidentate, chelating/bridging bidentate, and bidentate (Chart ).

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group C2221 (no. 20). The fundamental building unit of 1 contains three cadmium ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, two TED ligands, and two coordinated H2O molecules (Figure ). The Cd1 center is coordinated by five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3A, O5B, and O6B) from three different CTC ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) from one TED ligand. Different from Cd1, the Cd2 center is bound by four CTC ligands (O2, O1C, O3A, and O3D) and two terminal H2O molecules (O7 and O7A). Carefully examining the structure of complex 1, we find that three octahedral Cd centers (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd1A) are bridged through six carboxyl groups, two in mode A, two in mode B, and two in mode C, respectively, to form an edged-sharing metallic trinuclear secondary building unit [Cd3(CO2)6N2] with a sandwiched structure (Figure a). First, Cd1 centers link CTC ligands to form an infinite 2D (6,3) network with about 9.6 × 9.6 Å2 channels running along the ab plane (Figure b). The octahedral coordination geometries of Cd2 centers connect two adjacent networks above to create a neutral alternating 2-fold (6,3) network [Cd3(CTC)2] (Figure c). The independent TED ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers vertically generating a layer-pillared 3D structure with open channels of approximately 7.2 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and 7.2 × 7.8 Å2 along the [110] direction (Figures d and S2 (in the )). The void space is filled with two protonated guest H3O+ and two chlorine ions as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

elements.content: The structure of 2 reveals that the framework is composed of a centrosymmetric trinuclear SBU [Cd3(CO2)6N2] (Figure a). Three Cd centers (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd1A) are bridged through six carboxyl groups: two in mode A, two in mode C, and two in mode D, respectively. All the SBUs further link with each other through cyclohexyl groups of CTC ligands to form a 2D 2-fold alternate (6,3) layer [Cd3(CTC)2] (Figure b). Then, adjacent (6,3) layers are pillared by the longer Bipy spacers into a noninterpenetrated 3D microporous MOF structure with channels of 11.3 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 11.3 × 7.8 Å2 along the b axis (Figures c and S3 (in the )). The channels are filled with two coordinated DMFs, one guest DMF, and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA.

elements.content: We expected that the longer pillar linker Bpe would lead to the larger pores. X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of 3 is similar to that of 2, and 3 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅ (no. 2). The fundamental building unit of 3 contains three cadmium ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, two Bpe ligands, and two coordinated DMF molecules (Figure b). As a consequence, the Bpe ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers along the c axis to lead to an extended open 3D framework with channels of 13.5 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 13.5 × 7.8 Å2 along the b axis (Figures d and S4 (in the )). The channels are filled with two coordinated DMFs, one guest DMF, and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA.

elements.content: The trinuclear Zn3 SBUas a molecular clusteris known in many complexes, such as MOF-3 and [Zn3(BDC)3(H2O)2]·4DMF. The structures of 4 and 5 reveal that the frameworks are composed of the typical Zn3 cluster units. Different from the foregoing trinuclear Cd3 cluster, the low-coordination number of zinc is helpful to avoid the unfavorable terminal coordination and to create larger channels.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/m (no. 12). The fundamental building unit of 4 contains three zinc ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, and two Bipy ligands (Figure a). The Zn1 center is coordinated by three oxygen atoms (O1, O4, and O4B) from three different CTC ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) from one Bipy ligand. Different from Zn1, the Zn2 center is bound by six CTC ligands (O1, O1A, O3, O3B, O3C, and O3D). As shown in Figure a, there are three Zn centers (Zn1, Zn2, and Zn1A), bound to six carboxylate groups. Here, the Zn1 center is a four-coordinated tetrahedron, the Zn2 center is a six-coordinated octahedron, and these carboxylate groups coordinate the Zn centers by mode A and mode D, which lead to a corner-sharing metallic trinuclear SBU [Zn3(CO2)6N2]. All the SBUs further link with each other through cyclohexyl groups of CTC ligands to form a new 2D 2-fold alternate (6,3) layer [Zn3(CTC)2] (Figure b). The independent Bipy ligand acts as a pillar to generate a layer-pillared 3D structure with a pore size of about 11.3 × 8.4 Å2 along the b axis and of 11.3 × 4 Å2 along the a axis (Figures c and S5 (in the )). The channels are filled with one guest DMF and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA.

elements.content: Better insight into the nature of MOFs can be achieved by the application of the topological approach, i.e., reducing a multidimensional structure to simple node-and-linker nets. To determine the topology of 1–5 based on the guideline presented above, each trinuclear SBU which is coordinated by six carboxylate groups from six separated CTC ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two linear N-donor ligands, respectively, can be considered as an 8-connected node. Similarly, each CTC ligating with three SBUs can act as a 3-connected node and a pillaring N-donor ligand ligating with two SBUs only serves as a bridged ligand. On the basis of the simplification principle, it should be noted that the network topologies of 1–5 are identical. Upon careful examination, we find that the M(Cd/Zn)-carboxylate layer has a 2-fold alternate 63 honeycomb topology (Figure a) which prevents an interpenetrating structure from forming. The resulting structure of compounds 1–5 is a binodal (3,8)-connected net with two 3-connected nodes (CTC ligands) and one 8-connected (trinuclear SBUs) node and a Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46·618·84) (the first symbol represents the CTC ligand, and the second, the trinuclear SBU; Figure b).

elements.content: The coordination geometries of Cd2+ in compounds 1–3 are slightly different from those of Zn2+ in compounds 4 and 5 in which the Cd2+ is octahedrally coordinated whereas the Zn2+ is both octahedrally and tetrahedrally coordinated. The extra two coordination sites around Cd2+ are occupied by the terminal solvent molecules (H2O or DMF) in compounds 1–3, allowing them to maintain the same framework topologies as those of compounds 4 and 5.

elements.content: To study adsorption properties, the water adsorption isotherms of 1–5 were measured at room temperature (ca. 20 °C), respectively. Before the measurement, the samples of 1–5 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h and then heated at 80 °C for 4 h to remove the noncoordinated solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of exchanged samples of 1–5 were identical to that of as-synthesized samples, only with slightly weakened intensity, respectively, which indicates that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation. As shown in Figure , the water sorption isotherms exhibit two uptakes. In all cases the water sorption isotherms revealed type I isotherms in the range about P/P 0 = 0−0.70, which clearly indicates that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. The second increase in the range above P/P 0 > 0.70 is attributed to sorption on the external crystallite surface, which is similar to some reported MOFs. At the first saturation, the amounts of 1–5 adsorbed are 72, 101, 116, 172, and 189 mg/g for H2O, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 15, 6, 7, 15, and 9 H2O molecules per unit cell. Therefore, the pore volumes are estimated to be approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g for compounds 1–5, respectively, by the water adsorption isotherms, which is comparable to those found in many zeolites. The increased water adsorption activity is consistent with the larger effective channel sizes of these complexes, which clearly shows that using longer ligands can produce porous materials with higher adsorption capacities. To encourage permanent microporosity, synthetic strategies must avoid channel clogging: such as excessive framework interpenetration or unfavorable terminal coordination. In compounds 1−5, the 2-fold alternate (6,3) M(Cd/Zn)-carboxylate layers have proven to be sufficiently effective to prohibit the interpenetrated structure. In addition, water sorption studies reveal that the adsorption in complexes 4 and 5 is higher than that in 2 and 3, which shows that the avoidance of terminal coordination solvent molecules has positive effects on the adsorption capacity: a decrease of sample mass, a decrease of sample density, and an increase of available micropore volume.

To study adsorption properties, the water adsorption isotherms of 1-5 were measured at room temperature (ca. 20 °C), respectively. elements.content: The photoluminescent spectra of the free CTC ligand, Bipy ligand, Bpe ligand, and compounds 1−5 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The emission band for free CTC ligand is at 570 nm excited at 396 nm, which may be attributed to the π* → n transition. The emission band for free Bipy ligand is at 437 nm excited at 357 nm and that of free Bpe ligand is at 445 nm excited at 361 nm, which could be attributed to the π* → π transition. In addition, the free TED ligand does not emit any luminescence in the range 400–700 nm. An intense emission peak of compound 1 is found at 522 nm with an excitation band at 235 nm, which is blue-shifted 48 nm compared with that of the pure CTC ligand. Unlike compound 1, when excited by 358 nm light, compound 2 exhibits a main band at 449 nm, which is red-shifted compared with that of the pure Bipy ligand, and a shoulder band at 550 nm, which is blue-shifted compared with that of the pure CTC ligand. Compound 3 exhibits a main emission band at 453 nm and a shoulder band at 556 nm excited at 345 nm. The emission spectrum for 4 shows a main band at 447 nm and a shoulder band at 552 nm with λex = 387 nm. Compound 5 has a main band at 456 nm and a shoulder band at 560 nm with λex = 338 nm. The red-shifted main emission bands of 2–5, compared with that of the pure Bipy or Bpe ligands, are probably related to the intraligand fluorescent emission; similar red shifts have been observed before. The blue-shifted emission bands of 1–5, compared with that of the pure CTC ligand, can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). Both N-donor and O-donor ligands show contribution to the fluorescent emission of compounds 2–5 simultaneously, which further demonstrated that mixed ligands could facilitate the incorporation of their merits. Therefore, these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials.

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized and characterized a series of novel 3D porous metal−organic frameworks in which metallic trinuclear secondary building units [M3(CO2)6N2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) are connected by flexible CTC ligands and length-controllable diamine pillars. The metal−CTC−diamine synthetic strategy allows a systematical variation of the metal or the pillar to construct a series of open frameworks without changing the topology. The comparison of pore size, water adsorption data, and luminescence properties for compounds 1–5 are summarized in Table . The water adsorption isotherms show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions. Considering the water adsorption and fluorescent properties, these materials can be anticipated as having potential applications as multifunctional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized and characterized a series of novel 3D porous metal-organic frameworks in which metallic trinuclear secondary building units [M3(CO2)6N2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) are connected by flexible CTC ligands and length-controllable diamine pillars. The metal-CTC-diamine synthetic strategy allows a systematical variation of the metal or the pillar to construct a series of open frameworks without changing the topology. The comparison of pore size, water adsorption data, and luminescence properties for compounds 1-5 are summarized in Table . The water adsorption isotherms show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions. Considering the water adsorption and fluorescent properties, these materials can be anticipated as having potential applications as multifunctional materials.

X-ray crystallography reveals that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group C2221 (no. 20). The fundamental building unit of 1 contains three cadmium ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, two TED ligands, and two coordinated H2O molecules (Figure ). The Cd1 center is coordinated by five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3A, O5B, and O6B) from three different CTC ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) from one TED ligand. Different from Cd1, the Cd2 center is bound by four CTC ligands (O2, O1C, O3A, and O3D) and two terminal H2O molecules (O7 and O7A). Carefully examining the structure of complex 1, we find that three octahedral Cd centers (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd1A) are bridged through six carboxyl groups, two in mode A, two in mode B, and two in mode C, respectively, to form an edged-sharing metallic trinuclear secondary building unit [Cd3(CO2)6N2] with a sandwiched structure (Figure a). First, Cd1 centers link CTC ligands to form an infinite 2D (6,3) network with about 9.6 × 9.6 Å2 channels running along the ab plane (Figure b). The octahedral coordination geometries of Cd2 centers connect two adjacent networks above to create a neutral alternating 2-fold (6,3) network [Cd3(CTC)2] (Figure c). The independent TED ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers vertically generating a layer-pillared 3D structure with open channels of approximately 7.2 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and 7.2 × 7.8 Å2 along the [110] direction (Figures d and S2 (in the )). The void space is filled with two protonated guest H3O+ and two chlorine ions as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

We expected that the longer pillar linker Bpe would lead to the larger pores. X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of 3 is similar to that of 2, and 3 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅ (no. 2). The fundamental building unit of 3 contains three cadmium ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, two Bpe ligands, and two coordinated DMF molecules (Figure b). As a consequence, the Bpe ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers along the c axis to lead to an extended open 3D framework with channels of 13.5 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 13.5 × 7.8 Å2 along the b axis (Figures d and S4 (in the )). The channels are filled with two coordinated DMFs, one guest DMF, and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA.

X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of 5 is similar to that of 4, and 5 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1 (no. 1). The fundamental building unit of 5 contains three zinc ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, and two Bpe ligands (Figure b). As a consequence, the Bpe ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers along the c axis to lead to an extended open 3D framework with channels of 13.5 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 13.5 × 7.6 Å2 along the [110] direction (Figures d and S6 (in the )). The channels are filled with one guest DMF and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA.

Water Sorption Properties of Complexes <bold>1</bold>–<bold>5</bold>

To study adsorption properties, the water adsorption isotherms of 1–5 were measured at room temperature (ca. 20 °C), respectively. Before the measurement, the samples of 1–5 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h and then heated at 80 °C for 4 h to remove the noncoordinated solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of exchanged samples of 1–5 were identical to that of as-synthesized samples, only with slightly weakened intensity, respectively, which indicates that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation. As shown in Figure , the water sorption isotherms exhibit two uptakes. In all cases the water sorption isotherms revealed type I isotherms in the range about P/P 0 = 0−0.70, which clearly indicates that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. The second increase in the range above P/P 0 > 0.70 is attributed to sorption on the external crystallite surface, which is similar to some reported MOFs. At the first saturation, the amounts of 1–5 adsorbed are 72, 101, 116, 172, and 189 mg/g for H2O, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 15, 6, 7, 15, and 9 H2O molecules per unit cell. Therefore, the pore volumes are estimated to be approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g for compounds 1–5, respectively, by the water adsorption isotherms, which is comparable to those found in many zeolites. The increased water adsorption activity is consistent with the larger effective channel sizes of these complexes, which clearly shows that using longer ligands can produce porous materials with higher adsorption capacities. To encourage permanent microporosity, synthetic strategies must avoid channel clogging: such as excessive framework interpenetration or unfavorable terminal coordination. In compounds 1−5, the 2-fold alternate (6,3) M(Cd/Zn)-carboxylate layers have proven to be sufficiently effective to prohibit the interpenetrated structure. In addition, water sorption studies reveal that the adsorption in complexes 4 and 5 is higher than that in 2 and 3, which shows that the avoidance of terminal coordination solvent molecules has positive effects on the adsorption capacity: a decrease of sample mass, a decrease of sample density, and an increase of available micropore volume.

Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized and characterized a series of novel 3D porous metal−organic frameworks in which metallic trinuclear secondary building units [M3(CO2)6N2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) are connected by flexible CTC ligands and length-controllable diamine pillars. The metal−CTC−diamine synthetic strategy allows a systematical variation of the metal or the pillar to construct a series of open frameworks without changing the topology. The comparison of pore size, water adsorption data, and luminescence properties for compounds 1–5 are summarized in Table . The water adsorption isotherms show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions. Considering the water adsorption and fluorescent properties, these materials can be anticipated as having potential applications as multifunctional materials.

As a consequence, the Bpe ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers along the c axis to lead to an extended open 3D framework with channels of 13.5 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 13.5 × 7.8 Å2 along the b axis (Figures d and S4 (in the )). The channels are filled with two coordinated DMFs, one guest DMF, and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA. 

X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of 5 is similar to that of 4, and 5 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1 (no. 1). The fundamental building unit of 5 contains three zinc ions, six crystallographically equivalent CTC ligands, and two Bpe ligands (Figure b). As a consequence, the Bpe ligand acts as a pillar to support the infinite 2-fold alternate (6,3) layers along the c axis to lead to an extended open 3D framework with channels of 13.5 × 8.4 Å2 along the a axis and of 13.5 × 7.6 Å2 along the [110] direction (Figures d and S6 (in the )). The channels are filled with one guest DMF and two guest H2O molecules as established by elemental analysis and TGA. 

Water Sorption Properties of Complexes 1-5 

To study adsorption properties, the water adsorption isotherms of 1-5 were measured at room temperature (ca. 20 °C), respectively. Before the measurement, the samples of 1-5 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h and then heated at 80 °C for 4 h to remove the noncoordinated solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of exchanged samples of 1-5 were identical to that of as-synthesized samples, only with slightly weakened intensity, respectively, which indicates that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation. As shown in Figure , the water sorption isotherms exhibit two uptakes. In all cases the water sorption isotherms revealed type I isotherms in the range about P/P 0 = 0-0.70, which clearly indicates that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. The second increase in the range above P/P 0 > 0.70 is attributed to sorption on the external crystallite surface, which is similar to some reported MOFs. At the first saturation, the amounts of 1-5 adsorbed are 72, 101, 116, 172, and 189 mg/g for H2O, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 15, 6, 7, 15, and 9 H2O molecules per unit cell. Therefore, the pore volumes are estimated to be approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g for compounds 1-5, respectively, by the water adsorption isotherms, which is comparable to those found in many zeolites. The increased water adsorption activity is consistent with the larger effective channel sizes of these complexes, which clearly shows that using longer ligands can produce porous materials with higher adsorption capacities. To encourage permanent microporosity, synthetic strategies must avoid channel clogging: such as excessive framework interpenetration or unfavorable terminal coordination. In compounds 1-5, the 2-fold alternate (6,3) M(Cd/Zn)-carboxylate layers have proven to be sufficiently effective to prohibit the interpenetrated structure. In addition, water sorption studies reveal that the adsorption in complexes 4 and 5 is higher than that in 2 and 3, which shows that the avoidance of terminal coordination solvent molecules has positive effects on the adsorption capacity: a decrease of sample mass, a decrease of sample density, and an increase of available micropore volume. 

Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized and characterized a series of novel 3D porous metal-organic frameworks in which metallic trinuclear secondary building units [M3(CO2)6N2] (M2+ = Cd2+ or Zn2+) are connected by flexible CTC ligands and length-controllable diamine pillars. The metal-CTC-diamine synthetic strategy allows a systematical variation of the metal or the pillar to construct a series of open frameworks without changing the topology. The comparison of pore size, water adsorption data, and luminescence properties for compounds 1-5 are summarized in Table . The water adsorption isotherms show type Ι behavior with approximately 0.07, 0.10, 0.12, 0.17, and 0.19 mL/g pore volumes, respectively. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that they display strong emission in the blue/green regions. Considering the water adsorption and fluorescent properties, these materials can be anticipated as having potential applications as multifunctional materials.
